Strengthening Human Resource Development 
Cooperation in the Greater Mekong Subregion 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Economic Cooperation Program launched in 
1992 promotes closer economic ties and cooperation among the six countries1 that share the 
Mekong River.  Home to about 300 million people, the subregion with its rich human and natural 
resources presents vast opportunities and challenges for cooperation and integration in the 
continuing efforts to reduce poverty, achieve sustainable growth, and improve living standards. 
The  GMS  Program  is  anchored  on  three  pillars:  enhanced  connectivity,  increased 
competitiveness, and a greater sense of community. To date, the GMS Program has promoted 
subregional  cooperation  in  the  following  key  sectors:  transportation,  energy, 
telecommunications,  human  resource  development  (HRD),  tourism,  environment,  trade, 
investment, and agriculture. 
2.   A 10-year GMS strategic framework (GMS-SF) (2002–2012), founded on a common 
vision for an integrated, prosperous, and more equitably developed Mekong subregion, was 
endorsed by GMS countries at the 10th GMS Ministerial Conference in 2002. The SF identifies 
HRD as one of the five strategic areas of cooperation, as it has the potential to enhance 
competitiveness  and  increase  the  returns  from  connectivity,  while  building  a  sense  of 
community  through  collective  action  on  common  cross-border  HRD  concerns.  The  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) has been actively supporting the GMS Working Group on HRD 
(WGHRD) to facilitate cooperation on HRD issues since its establishment in 1996. Successful 
HRD initiatives include the well-known Phnom Penh Plan for Development Management, which 
focuses  on  building  the  capacity  of  senior  and  middle-level  public  officials  and  promotes 
dialogue on key development issues of interest to GMS countries. 
 
3.  Despite  the  strong  and  active  interest  in  regional  HRD  initiatives,  subregional 
cooperation and activities have been difficult, given the multisectoral nature and the lack of a 
HRD SF. This regional technical assistance (RETA)2 is being undertaken to assist the GMS 
WGHRD in preparing a SF and an action plan to identify a common vision and outline strategic 
priorities to be pursued over the medium term. The TA design and monitoring framework 
identifying the main inputs, outputs, and outcome of the RETA is in Appendix 1.  
 
 
II.  ISSUES  
4.  Although the WGHRD has been in existence since 1996 and has implemented 17 
projects, generating substantive regional cooperation for HRD issues has been difficult for a 
number of reasons. First, the multisectoral nature of HRD requires different sector agencies to 
collaborate on common issues and this task has not been easy since government agencies tend 
to be focused on their individual sector issues. Second, GMS countries are at various stages of 
development and while the benefits of cooperation are recognized, it has been difficult to 
identify joint HRD activities. Third, the momentum of WGHRD deliberations, activities, and 
priorities  varied  over  the  past  decade  in  line  with  changing  country  representation. 
Consequently,  the  approach  to  subregional  cooperation  in  HRD  has  largely  been  ad  hoc, 
focused on the health sector, and lacks a clearly defined SF and comprehensive work program. 
These shortcomings have been recognized by both ADB and the WGHRD. 
 
                                                 
1  GMS countries include Cambodia, Yunnan Province and Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region of the People’s 
Republic of China, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Myanmar, Thailand, and Viet Nam.  
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 28 April 2007.

2   
5.  A recent midterm review3 of the GMS-SF (2002–2012) indicated that the GMS Program 
has made very good progress in the “hardware” aspects of cooperation, but emphasized that 
more effort is needed on the “software” components. More attention is required to transform 
improved  connectivity  into  accelerated  improvements  in  livelihood  activities  and  poverty 
reduction. Negative externalities associated with improved connectivity and mobility of people 
and goods, e.g., transmission of communicable diseases and illegal migration of workers, need 
particular attention. To strengthen the effectiveness of subregional cooperation in HRD, the Mid-
Term Review suggested (i) the formulation of a GMS-SF and action plan for HRD cooperation; 
(ii) strengthening of institutional arrangements and support to the WGHRD; and (iii) pursuit of 
cooperation in labor issues, e.g., labor migration, labor standards, human trafficking, skills 
competencies and standards, and protection of migrant workers.   
 
6.  Some emerging challenges for the WGHRD in defining a SF with  a clear set of priorities 
for  HRD  cooperation  include  (i)  effectively  addressing  the  intersectoral  nature  of  HRD  to 
maximize returns to investments, (ii) identifying key intersectoral HRD priorities common to the 
GMS  vs.  identifying  many  sector-specific  challenges,  (iii)  addressing  weak  institutional 
mechanisms for championing the HRD agenda within each GMS country and in the region as a 
whole, (iv) raising and directing resources for adequate investment in HRD, and (v) targeting 
assistance to deal with negative externalities arising from ongoing social and economic changes. 
 
7.  In the absence of an overall HRD SF, it has been difficult to prioritize HRD initiatives that 
explicitly link improvements in health and education with labor productivity, while simultaneously 
addressing potential social impacts of improved connectivity. Weak institutional mechanisms 
and frequently changing WGHRD membership has led to problems of (i) continuity and follow- 
through on the HRD agenda, (ii) weak coordination, and (iii) changing priorities. Without an 
overall HRD vision, the regional HRD challenges and agenda will not be realized. 
 
8.  HRD needs to be considered in an intersectoral context, since returns to HRD are 
greatest  when  synergies  are  built  between  investments  in  health,  education,  and  labor 
productivity. Some major issues identified and discussed by WGHRD-8 (May 2007) highlight the 
intersectoral  nature  of  problems  to  be  addressed.  For  instance,  measures  for  increasing 
competitiveness of the GMS, such as increasing opportunities for cross-border training and 
accreditation of workers, would provide greater benefits if they are matched with improvements 
in labor migration policies. In the education sector, key regional challenges continue to be the 
need to improve the quality of education in general, and skills training in particular. For instance, 
the  development  of  harmonized  skills  standards  and  accreditation  is  required  to  support 
increased and improved labor mobility. Mutual recognition of qualification standards especially 
in the area of technical and vocational training would facilitate and support labor mobility across 
the region. In the longer term, mutual recognition of diplomas and degrees would require the 
development of common standards and comparability. In the health sector, the challenge for the 
subregion is the current low priority accorded to improving the delivery of health services for the 
poor,  and  understanding  just  how  vital  that  is  for  education  attainment  as  well  as  labor 
productivity. Key challenges are, therefore, improvements in public health financing, health 
systems  development,  and  better  regulation  by  explicitly  making  the

linkage between improved health outcomes, labor productivity, and poverty reduction among 
those  healthy  enough  to  be  employed.  The  WGHRD  can  provide  an  excellent  forum  for 
developing  the  common  standards,  exchange  of  information  and  formulating  strategies  for 
improved cooperation and collaboration in this regard. Appendix 2 outlines four relevant inter-
sectoral approaches to HRD that will need to be considered by the WGHRD to help identify 
priorities for regional cooperation over the medium term.   
 
9.  Finally, investments in HRD relate both to raising the quality of human resources and to 
addressing the potential negative impacts associated with rapidly changing economic and social 
environments.  Some  of  the  more  severe  negative  effects  from  increased  connectivity  and 
regional integration relate to spread of HIV/AIDS and other communicable diseases, female and 
child trafficking, and illegal migration. The HRD SF will need to identify means to effectively 
tackle these negative externalities that can erode gains from investment in HRD. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The intended impact of the RETA is enhanced cooperation in HRD in the GMS. The 
outcome is an agreed-upon HRD agenda for the GMS over the medium term. The latter will be 
achieved through the development of a HRD SF and an accompanying action plan to be 
considered by the GMS Senior Officials. Endorsement by the GMS countries of the SF will bring 
focus to the WGHRD and galvanize commitment to implement HRD priorities and initiatives to 
support implementation of the GMS strategic development framework for 2007–2012. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The  RETA  will  be  implemented  through  a  consultative  process  involving  multiple 
stakeholders. It will include (i) a review of the WGHRD (1–8) proceedings, (ii) a review of 
relevant reports of ADB and GMS governments and partners; (iii) consultative meetings and 
workshops  with  government,  nongovernment  agencies,  and  development  partners  in  each  
GMS country; and (iv) review of HRD development strategies and best practices pursued by 
other countries in the GMS. The RETA will support three specific outputs and related activities 
outlined below: 
 
  1.  A Comprehensive GMS-HRD Strategic Framework 
 
12.  The SF to be developed by the WGHRD through consultation with stakeholders will (i) 
include the vision and mission statements for HRD in the GMS, (ii) identify key strategies for 
achieving them, (iii) outline the core programs/priority initiatives for the medium term, (iv) identify 
resource requirements for priority initiatives, (v) identify strategic alliances and partnerships with 
academic/policy advisory institutes, and (vi) propose institutional mechanisms for HRD. The SF 
will  be  formally  reviewed  and  revised  every  3  years  by  the  WGHRD  so  as  to  ensure  its 
continuing relevance. 
 
  2.  An HRD Action Plan for Priority Initiatives  
 
13.  An action plan for HRD cooperation will be prepared and will include priority initiatives to 
be pursued over the medium term. The action plan will take into consideration (i) common 
potential  benefits  to  GMS  countries,  (ii)  the  implementing  capacity  in  the  countries,  (iii)

4 
ongoing regional initiatives led by other regional cooperation bodies such as the Association of 
Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN),  and  (iv)  support  for  HRD  being  provided  by  other 
development partners. Examples of potential initiatives include developing harmonized skills 
standards and accreditation, adopting common labor standards and safe migration policies,  
recognizing  cross-border  health  certification,  and  measures  to  improve  surveillance  and 
cooperation on cross-border communicable diseases. Initiatives for HRD cooperation will be 
carefully chosen to avoid overlap with ongoing initiatives within the subregion.  
 
  3.  Consultation Mechanisms for Continuing GMS Cooperation on HRD Issues 
 
14.  While the SF will identify formal institutional structures to support HRD, the RETA will 
support  subsector  dialogue  and  consultation  among  GMS  countries  on  priority  initiatives 
identified above. Support will be provided for convening consultative meetings/workshops of the 
WGHRD from November 2007 to October 2008. 
 
15.  The  main  assumptions  for  achieving  the  outputs  relate  to  (i)  the  willingness  of 
development partners to share information on their current and future regional HRD initiatives, (ii) 
appropriate level of representation and feedback from the government and stakeholders, and (iii) 
effective coordination of implementation arrangements. The main risk from outputs achieving 
the outcome is that national HRD priorities may take precedence over regional priorities. The SF 
will identify measures to reduce that risk.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
16.  The total cost of the TA is $200,000 financed on a grant basis by ADB’s technical 
assistance funding program. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the Executing Agency of the RETA, while the Social Sectors Division of the 
Southeast  Asia  Department  of  ADB  will  be  the  Implementing  Agency.  The  GMS  national 
WGHRD focal points, in consultation with the GMS WGHRD sector-specific focal persons, will 
be responsible for (i) coordinating activities for priority initiatives identified under the HRD SF; (ii) 
developing and invigorating partnerships between the WGHRD, civil society, the private sector 
and development partners; and (iii) actively seeking national and regional resources to continue 
the work of the WGHRD beyond that financed under the RETA. The RETA will be implemented 
over 12 months (November 2007–October 2008). 
 
18.  The  RETA  will  require  3  person-months  of  international  and  12  person-months  of 
national consulting services, with direct selection of individual consultants. The international 
consultant  will  be  a  specialist  in  HRD  strategy  and  program  development.  The  national 
consultant will support the international consultant in developing the HRD SF as well as facilitate 
work related to the WGHRD. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. 
The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants 2007 (as amended from time to time).  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Human Resource Development Cooperation in the Greater Mekong Subregion, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

FOUR APPROACHES TO HUMAN RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT 
 
1.   Background.    The  significant  progress  in  socioeconomic  reforms  and  reduction  in 
poverty rates in the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) since the mid-1980s is attributable in a 
large part to the subregion’s increased openness to regional and global markets and to steady 
structural and regulatory reforms.1 Current measures outlined by GMS countries to further 
promote investment and enhance productivity include the development of human resources 
through health, education, and training services; transformation of state-owned enterprises; 
investments  in  small-  and  large-scale  infrastructure;  development  of  transparent  legal  and 
regulatory  frameworks;  and  strengthening  of  the  banking  and  financial  services  sectors. 
Regional integration with more developed countries such as People’s Republic of China, Japan, 
Republic of Korea, and Thailand is also recognized as essential for further development of GMS 
countries.  
 
2.   Accompanying the gains in gross domestic product growth rates and decline in the 
poverty rates2 have been an increase in income inequalities between rural and urban areas and 
rising income differentials between skilled and unskilled workers. In addition, a number of cross-
border problems arising from disparities in development of GMS countries vis-à-vis their more 
developed neighbors (such as illegal labor migration, human trafficking, and potential for a rise 
in communicable diseases) have emerged. If unchecked, such problems could lead to tensions 
and threaten the sensitive economic and social balance in the region. 
 
3.   Approaches.  Human  resource  development  (HRD)  essentially  occurs  within  an 
intersectoral context. The following key approaches to HRD will need to be explored in the 
process of developing the GMS HRD strategic framework, so as to identify areas with the 
greatest potential to contribute to social and economic development in the GMS over the 
medium term:      
 
(i)  Human development through integrated health and education programs. 
This  approach  relates  to  measures  of  human  development  captured  in  the 
human development index and reflected in the Millennium Development Goals. 
All GMS countries are focusing on this aspect, but there appears to be a need for 
better integration of programs involving nutrition, cognitive development, and 
basic  health  conditions  for  children  that  set  the  pace  for  human  capital 
development and competitiveness in the future. This HRD perspective will be of 
particular relevance to countries affected by increased migration of caregivers, 
which can have an adverse impact on health and learning abilities (despite the 
increase in remittances and income). It therefore has implications for how public 
policy in education and health services can be better integrated and how these 
services  can  be  better  delivered,  to  contribute  to  both  the  “community”  and 
“competitiveness” elements of the overall GMS strategy.

(ii)  Human capital development through skills training directed at domestic 
and regional economic growth hubs. This approach to HRD is particularly 
attractive for countries that are industrializing and includes investment in short- to 
medium-term skills training, particularly for the youth (16–25 years of age), to 
fulfill the emerging requirements for industrial and services growth hubs. This 
approach  also  requires  a  multisectoral  and  regional  response,  given  the 
increased connectivity and increasing migration of labor within GMS countries 
and  to  neighboring  countries.  Intersectoral  policy  issues  related  to  skills 
standards, accreditation of skills, health insurance schemes, minimum working 
conditions,  social  protection,  and  labor  regulation/contractual  obligations  will 
need to be explored in terms of how they are affected by increased connectivity 
and competitiveness.     
 
(iii)  Human resource development within the public services. This approach will 
meet the requirements of transitioning economies through training for legislation 
and  regulation  to  attract  investment,  corporatize/privatize  state-owned 
enterprises, as well as deal with retrenchment issues. To a certain extent, this 
approach is being followed under the Phnom Penh Plan. This regional technical 
assistance can explore initiatives for training in certain sectors that may be of 
relevance and interest to all GMS countries, such as energy privatization and 
regulation, water resource development and management, or skills for translating 
requirements of the World Trade Organization into national laws and regulations. 
 
(iv)  Specific  interventions  to  address  negative  externalities  arising  from 
increased  connectivity  in  the  region.  This  approach  will  address  illegal 
migration and exploitation, human trafficking, and communicable diseases as 
externalities that cause investments in HRD to deteriorate. Some of these issues 
can  be  addressed  by  separate  strategies  being  developed  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for health and education and the one developed for 
addressing human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Human  Resource  Development  (HRD)  Strategy  and  Program  Development 
Specialist (international, 3 person-months, intermittent) 
1.  The specialist will have a degree in the social sciences or any other relevant degree. 
The  specialist  is  expected  to  have  (i)  extensive  experience  in  developing  national  and/or 
regional strategies for HRD, (ii) knowledge of regional cooperation strategies in HRD that have 
been developed or are currently being developed by other development partners, and (iii) a 
sound understanding of the policy making and resource allocation mechanisms in countries in 
the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS). In addition, the specialist must demonstrate excellent 
facilitation and problem-solving skills and have an aptitude for conveying complex ideas in 
simple language. The specialist will undertake the following tasks. 
(i)  Analyze current policies and priorities for HRD in GMS countries and those 
identified  for  the  region  by  the  Working  Group  on  Human  Resource 
Development (WGHRD). 
(ii)  Undertake consultations with WGHRD members; relevant officials of the health, 
education,  and  labor  agencies;  staff  at  resident  missions;  and  other  key-
stakeholders, including development partners and the nongovernment sector. 
(iii)  Seek  ways  to  develop  or  improve  public  policies  for  subregional  HRD 
cooperation, especially as they relate to skills development, labor migration, and 
social protection of cross-border workers. 
(iv)  Help  GMS  governments  identify  institutional  arrangements  to  support  and 
sustain HRD initiatives within and across different sectors so as to maintain the 
momentum of activities between meetings of the WGHRD. 
(v)  Work closely with development partners in ensuring complementary approaches 
and program designs for sustaining efforts for HRD in the GMS. Identify suitable 
sources of cofinancing initiatives where possible. 
(vi)  Prepare the draft strategic framework and action plan for priority initiatives for 
the WGHRD. 
(vii)  Present the draft strategic framework for cooperation on HRD at the Senior 
Officials’  Meeting  (SOM)  and  make  appropriate  revisions  to  finalize  the 
document.  
 
(viii)  Identify local and regional nongovernment and private sector agencies/research 
institutes that could be consulted by the WGHRD to ensure the relevance of HRD 
policies and plans reflected in the strategic framework. These resources could be 
used to develop knowledge products emerging from the WGHRD’s experience in 
trying to implement regional cooperation initiatives for HRD. 
 
(ix)  Identify ways to improve the design, implementation, and management of Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) support to HRD in the GMS. 
 
(x)  Develop and supervise the work of the national consultant.

Appendix 4             11 
 
Location:  Manila, Philippines, with regional travel, as required.

  2.  Action plan for priority initiatives for the WGHRD 
 
B.  National Consultant(s) (12 person-months)  
2.  The national consultant(s) will have a postgraduate degree in social sciences as well as 
5–8 years experience in education/labor and/or health/social development. The consultant(s) 
will be computer literate and have strong analytical and report writing skills. The following are 
the consultant’s tasks. 
 
(i)  Identify  and  consolidate  national  and  regional  HRD  policies  and  strategy 
documents, and prepare summary analysis.  
 
(ii)  Work in close coordination with the WGHRD focal points and the international

(iii)  Participate, as needed, with the international consultant in consultations with 
stakeholders from among the development partners, the private sector, and local

(iv)  Provide support, as needed, to GMS senior officials in preparing presentations 
on HRD for their countries, which are supportive of agreed-upon priorities for
